Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: FishLife: genealogy and traits of living and fossil vertebrates that never left the water
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop and apply a unified framework for studying the evolution of all fishes, including lampreys, sharks, and the coral reef, deep sea and freshwater fishes. This work will illuminate the genealogical relationships (phylogeny), evolutionary timing, and mechanisms for the origin and maintenance of the world's diversity of fishes, including the most important food and aquarium fishes. The project will contribute to community-driven scientific efforts, to student training, to web content and application development, and to public outreach. All fish specimens, specimen and DNA data, and analytical results obtained will be made publicly available through a dynamic and open structure that complies with established standards to facilitate wide accessibility to the broader scientific and non-scientific communities. High school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral student training are central activities for this project. Social media outreach and training will provide diverse professional development opportunities as well. A fish species identification application for smartphones based on image data (FishSnap) will be developed and made freely available to the public to allow accurate identification of selected groups of fishes. Outcomes of this project will form part of a new public exhibit at the National Museum of Natural History to highlight the value of specimen collections at natural history museums.

This integrative project will combine genomic, paleontological, anatomical, functional, ecological, and comparative approaches. The research team blends strengths in collections-based research on fishes, molecular and morphological phylogenetics, bioinformatics, and comparative analyses, allowing them to synthesize big data sets to resolve the phylogeny of all described fish species and conduct evolutionary analysis of key traits. Time-calibrated trees will be used to reveal diversification patterns of the major groups. Image analysis, morphometrics, and phenomic data will enable the discovery of evolutionary patterns in size, shape, and biomechanical function across thousands of species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Our component of NSF collaborative award 1541556  “FishLife: genealogy and traits of living and fossil vertebrates that never left the water” was to estimate the evolutionary relationships among the major groups of ling sharks skates rays and chimaeras based on DNA sequence comparisons. We collected tissue samples from representatives of all described families of sharks skates and rays, 95% of all described genera and about 70% of all species from all over the world. We designed a target capture approach, based on gene specific RNA baits to amplify complete mitochondrial genomes and a pre-identified set of slowly-evolving protein-coding genes that we had previously shown would work across all species of sharks, skates, rays and chimaeras.  This represented the most comprehensive effort to understand the evolutionary history of sharks and rays undertaken to date. 

 

Over the course of the project we discovered and described several new species of sharks and rays. In most cases these were  discovered because they had unique DNA sequences  that were unlike any others and then were found to also have  subtle morphological differences from species to which they were closely related.. Our analyses have revealed a number of new and important findings about elasmobranchs. We found, for example, that all of the New world guitar fishes distributed around North and South America  are a monophyletic group. In other words they are all derived from a North American common ancestor.  Accodingly we have changed the taxonomy of guitar fishes to reflect these by erecting a new genus "Pseudobatos" that is applied to all the New World Guitar Fishes. This has important implications for biogeography as it suggests that continental masses  explain   the distribution of these animals much better than do ocean basins, which reflects their  tight dependence on coastal habitats and underscores why it is so important for us to protect our coastal continental shelf habitats. We have also been able to confirm that Guitarfishes and Sawfishes are each other’s closest relatives. This has been suggested before based on overall body shape, but never explicitly proven. Accordingly the two previously recognized elasmobranch orders Pristiformes and Rhinobatiformes have been joined into one: the Rhinopristiformes. Other findings have provoked more questions than answers. In some elasmobranchs it appears that there are clear morphological differences between species that are not supported by  corresponding differences  in their DNA sequences (eg the deep water skates Bathyraja and  the charismatic mobulid devil rays);  whereas in other groups the exact opposite pattern holds: deeply divergent DNA sequences among individuals that appear morpjhologically identical.  It is not yet clear what processes account for these diametrically opposing patterns groups but we plan to explore them going forward   as we  believe they may shed light on why this lineage of  animals (chondrichthyan fishes) have managed to persist for over 400 million years,  weather  the two largest extinction events on earth while exhibiting relatively little morphological diversification relative to their counterparts bony fishes:

Broader Impacts.

We have developed a website https:sharksrays.org that has become widely used and appears popular both among the scientific community and the general public. The website has illustrations of all of the described species of chondrichthyans, their associated ranges and their inferred phylogenetic relationships depicted  on an interactive GUI. The website has attracted quite  a lot of attention attention and has been incorporated into a new permanent interactive exhibit  on sharks   at the Georgia Aquarium The Georgia Aquarium  typically hosts between 2 and 3 million visitors each year. We have also given a number of lectures to k-12 school groups about sharks and have discussed the project when interviewed on radio and television.
